article.paragraph: Dwight David"Ike"Eisenhower(pronouncedIPAc-enˈaɪzənhaʊər,respellEYESən-how-ər; October 14, 1890  March 28, 1969) was theList of Presidents of the United States34thPresident of the United Statesfrom 1953 until 1961, and the last U.S. President to have been born in the 19th century. He was aGeneral of the Army (United States)five-star generalin theUnited States ArmyduringWorld War IIand served asSupreme Commander of the Allied Expeditionary ForceSupreme Commanderof theAllies of World War IIAllied Forcesin Europe. He was responsible for planning and supervising the invasion of North Africa inOperation Torchin 194243 and the successfulInvasion of Normandyinvasion of FranceandAllied advance from Paris to the RhineGermanyin 194445 from theWestern Front (World War II)Western Front. In 1951, he became the firstSupreme Allied Commander EuropeSupreme Commander of NATO.cite webhttp://www.aco.nato.int/page61411944.aspxFormer SACEURsAco.nato.intJanuary 26, 2012

Eisenhower was ofPennsylvania Dutchancestry and was raised in a large family in Kansas by parents with a strong religious background. He graduated fromUnited States Military AcademyWest Pointand later married and had two sons. After World War II, Eisenhower served asChief of Staff of the United States ArmyArmy Chief of Staffunder PresidentHarry S. Trumanand then accepted the post of President atColumbia University.Ambrose, Stephen E. (1983).Eisenhower: Soldier, General of the Army, President-Elect, 18901952

Eisenhower entered the 1952 presidential race as aRepublican Party (United States)Republicanto counter the non-interventionism of SenatorRobert A. Taft, campaigning against "communism, Korea and corruption". He won in a landslide, defeating Democratic candidateAdlai Stevenson IIAdlai Stevensonand temporarily upending theNew Deal Coalition.

Eisenhower's main goals in office were to keep pressure on theSoviet Unionand reduce federal deficits. In the first year of his presidency, he threatened the use of nuclear weapons in order to conclude theKorean War; hisNew Look (policy)New Lookpolicy ofnuclear deterrenceprioritized inexpensiveNuclear weapons and the United Statesnuclear weaponswhile reducing funding for conventional military forces. In 1954, Eisenhower rejected the use of military force to help the French retain their colony of Vietnam. Congress agreed to his request in 1955 for theFormosa Resolution of 1955Formosa Resolution, which obliged the U.S. to militarily support the pro-Western Republic of China in Taiwan and continue the ostracism of thePeople's Republic of China.

After the Soviet Union launchedSputnik Ithe world's first artificial satellitein 1957, EisenhowerNational Aeronautics and Space Actauthorizedthe establishment ofNASA, which led to thespace race. During theSuez Crisisof 1956, Eisenhower condemned the Israeli, British and French invasion of Egypt, and forced them to withdraw. He also condemned the Soviet invasion during theHungarian Revolution of 1956but took no action. In 1958, Eisenhower sent 15,000 U.S. troops to Lebanon to prevent the pro-Western government from falling to aNasser-inspired revolution. Near the end of his term, his efforts to set up a summit meeting with the Soviets collapsed because of the1960 U-2 incidentU-2 incident.Arthur Schlesinger Jr.A Thousand Days: John F. Kennedy in the White House(1965), pp. 233, 238In his January 17, 1961Eisenhower's farewell addressfarewell address to the nation, Eisenhower expressed his concerns about the dangers of corporate control of Congress and massive military spending, particularly deficit spending and government contracts to private military manufacturers, and coined the term "militaryindustrial complexmilitary-industrial complex".cite webhttp://schott.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/01/25/guest-post-james-ledbetter-on-50-years-of-the-military-industrial-complex/Guest Post: 50 Years of the "Military–Industrial Complex"LedbetterJames25 January 2011Schott's Vocab[[New York Times]]25 January 2011

On the domestic front, he covertly opposedJoseph McCarthyand contributed to the end of McCarthyism by openly invoking the modern expanded version ofexecutive privilege. He otherwise left most political activity to his Vice President,Richard Nixon. He was a moderateConservatism in the United Statesconservativewho continuedNew Dealagencies and expandedSocial Security (United States)Social Security. He also launched theInterstate Highway System, theDARPADefense Advanced Research Projects Agency(DARPA), the establishment of strong science education via theNational Defense Education Act, and encouraged peaceful use of nuclear power via amendments to theAtomic Energy Act.Dwight D. Eisenhower and Science & Technology, (2008).Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial Commission,Source.

As a part of his domestic policy, he sent federal troops toLittle Rock, Arkansas, for the first time sinceReconstruction era (United States)Reconstructionto enforce federal court orders to desegregate public schools. He also signed civil rights legislation in 1957 and 1960 to protect the right to vote. He implemented desegregation of the armed forces in two years and made five appointments to the Supreme Court. He was the first term-limited president in accordance with theTwenty-second Amendment to the United States Constitution22nd Amendment.Eisenhower's two terms saw considerable economic prosperity except for a sharp recession in 195859. Voted Gallup's most admired man twelve times, he achieved widespread popular esteem both in and out of office.cite webhttp://www.gallup.com/poll/1678/most-admired-man-woman.aspxMost Admired Man and WomanGallup, Inc.Gallup.comAugust 26, 2015Since the late 20th century, consensus among Western scholars has consistentlyHistorical rankings of Presidents of the United States#Scholar survey resultsheldEisenhower as one of the greatest U.S. Presidents.
article.heading: Early life and education
article.paragraph: File:Eisenhower familyhome.jpgthumb250pxpxThe Eisenhower family home,Abilene, Kansas.The Eisenhauer (German for "iron hewer/miner") family migrated fromKarlsbrunn,Germany, to North America, first settling inYork, Pennsylvania, in 1741, and in the 1880s moving toKansas.cite newshttps://books.google.com/books?idGeneral "Ike" EisenhowerLifeNovember 9, 1942May 31, 2011Barnett, Lincoln112Accounts vary as to how and when the German name Eisenhauer wasAnglicisationanglicizedto Eisenhower.cite newshttps://books.google.com/books?idIke: An American HeroKorda,Michael2007July 22, 201263Eisenhower'sPennsylvania Dutchancestors, who were primarily farmers, included Hans Nikolaus Eisenhauer of Karlsbrunn, who migrated toLancaster, Pennsylvania, in 1741.Ambrose (1983), p. 14.

Hans's great-great-grandson, David Jacob Eisenhower (18631942), was Dwight's father and was a college-educated engineer, despite his own father Jacob's urging to stay on the family farm. Eisenhower's mother,Ida Stover EisenhowerIda Elizabeth (Stover) Eisenhower, born in Virginia, of German Protestant ancestry, moved to Kansas from Virginia. She married David on September 23, 1885, inLecompton, Kansas, on the campus of their alma mater,Lane University.Ambrose (1983), p. 1618.

David owned a general store inHope, Kansas, but the business failed due to economic conditions and the family became impoverished. The Eisenhowers then lived in Texas from 1889 until 1892, and later returned to Kansas, with $24 to their name at the time. David worked as a mechanic with a railroad and then with a creamery.By 1898, the parents made a decent living and provided a suitable home for their large family.Ambrose (1983), p. 19.

Eisenhower was born on October 14, 1890, inDenison, Texas, the third of seven boys.cite bookD'EsteCarloEisenhower: A Soldier's Life2003New York, New YorkMacmillan0-8050-5687-430https://books.google.com/books?idHis mother originally named him David Dwight but reversed the two names after his birth to avoid the confusion of having two Davids in the family.Ambrose (1983), p. 18.All of the boys were called "Ike", such as "Big Ike" (Edgar) and "Little Ike" (Dwight); the nickname was intended as an abbreviation of their last name.Ambrose (1983), p. 22.By World War II, only Dwight was still called "Ike".rbarnett19421109

In 1892, the family moved toAbilene, Kansas, which Eisenhower considered his home town.rbarnett19421109As a child, he was involved in an accident that cost his younger brother an eye; he later referred to this as an experience teaching him the need to be protective of those under him. Dwight developed a keen and enduring interest in exploring outdoors, hunting/fishing, cooking and card playing from an illiterate named Bob Davis who camped on theSmoky Hill River.D'Este, Carlo (2002).Eisenhower: A Soldier's Life, p. 25.cite webhttp://home.nps.gov/eise/forteachers/classrooms/upload/webed-Molding-of-a-Leader-Lesson-3-Materials.pdfGetting on the Right TRRACCLesson Plans: The Molding of a LeaderEisenhower National Historic SiteApril 27, 2013...Ike spent his weekends at Davis's camp on the Smoky Hill River.

While Eisenhower's mother was against war, it was her collection of history books that first sparked Eisenhower's early and lasting interest in military history. He persisted in reading the books in her collection and became a voracious reader in the subject. Other favorite subjects early in his education were arithmetic and spelling.Ambrose (1983), p. 32.

His parents set aside specific times at breakfast and at dinner for daily family Bible reading. Chores were regularly assigned and rotated among all the children, and misbehavior was met with unequivocal discipline, usually from David.Ambrose (1983), p. 25.His mother, previously a member (with David) of theRiver Brethrensect of theMennonites, joined theBible Student movement#International Bible Students AssociationInternational Bible Students Association, later known asJehovah's Witnesses. The Eisenhower home served as the local meeting hall from 1896 to 1915, though Eisenhower never joined the International Bible Students.Bergman, Jerry. "Steeped in Religion: President Eisenhower and the Influence of the Jehovah's Witnesses",Kansas History(autumn 1998).His later decision to attend West Point saddened his mother, who felt that warfare was "rather wicked," but she did not overrule him.D'Este, Carlo (2002).Eisenhower: A Soldier's Life, p. 58.While speaking of himself in 1948, Eisenhower said he was "one of the most deeply religious men I know" though unattached to any "sect or organization". He was baptized in thePresbyterian Church (U.S.A.)Presbyterian Churchin 1953.online "Faith Staked Down",Time, February 9, 1953.

Eisenhower attendedAbilene High School (Abilene, Kansas)Abilene High Schooland graduated with the class of 1909.Cite newsPublic School ProductsSeptember 14, 1959[[Time (magazine)|Time]]As a freshman, he injured his knee and developed a leg infection that extended into his groin, and which his doctor diagnosed as life-threatening. The doctor insisted that the leg be amputated but Dwight refused to allow it, and miraculously recovered, though he had to repeat his freshman year.Ambrose (1983), p. 36.He and brotherEdgar N. EisenhowerEdgarboth wanted to attend college, though they lacked the funds. They made a pact to take alternate years at college while the other worked to earn the tuitions.Ambrose (1983), p. 37.

Edgar took the first turn at school, and Dwight was employed as a night supervisor at the Belle Springs Creamery.Cite newsMay 23, 2008http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,839998-3,00.htmlEisenhower: Soldier of Peace[[Time (magazine)|Time]]April 4, 1969Edgar asked for a second year, Dwight consented and worked for a second year. At that time, a friend "Swede" Hazlet was applying to theUnited States Naval AcademyNaval Academyand urged Dwight to apply to the school, since no tuition was required. Eisenhower requested consideration for either Annapolis or West Point with his U.S. Senator,Joseph L. Bristow. Though Eisenhower was among the winners of the entrance-exam competition, he was beyond the age limit for the Naval Academy.cite webMay 23, 2008http://www.dwightdeisenhower.com/biodde.htmlBiography: Dwight David Eisenhower[[Eisenhower Foundation]]He then accepted an appointment to West Point in 1911.

File:Eisenhower Football.jpgthumb250pxEisenhower (2nd from left) andOmar Bradley(2nd from right) were members of the1912 Army Cadets football team1912 West Point football team.At West Point, Eisenhower relished the emphasis on traditions and on sports, but was less enthusiastic about the hazing, though he willingly accepted it as a plebe. He was also a regular violator of the more detailed regulations, and finished school with a less than stellar discipline rating. Academically, Eisenhower's best subject by far was English. Otherwise, his performance was average, though he thoroughly enjoyed the typical emphasis of engineering on science and mathematics.Ambrose (1983), p. 4448.

In athletics, Eisenhower later said that "not making the baseball team at West Point was one of the greatest disappointments of my life, maybe my greatest."cite webMay 23, 2008http://www.baseball-almanac.com/prz_qde.shtmlPresident Dwight D. Eisenhower Baseball Related QuotationsBaseball AlmanacHe did make the football team, and was a varsity starter as running back and linebacker in 1912, tackling the legendaryJim Thorpeof theCarlisle Indians footballCarlisle Indiansthat year.Cite newsMay 23, 2008http://www.cnn.com/2004/WORLD/europe/07/09/jim.thorpe/Roller-coaster life of Indian icon, sports' first starCNNJuly 15, 1912Botelho, GregEisenhower suffered a torn knee in that, his last, game; he re-injured his knee on horseback and in the boxing ring,rbarnett19421109Eisenhower, Dwight D. (1967). At Ease: Stories I Tell to Friends, Garden City, New York, Doubleday & Company, Inc.cite webMay 23, 2008http://www.eisenhowermemorial.org/stories/Ike-and-team.htmIke and the Team[[Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial]]so he turned to fencing and gymnastics.rbarnett19421109

Eisenhower later served as junior varsity football coach and cheerleader. At West Point he played football.cite webEisenhower BOQ 1915http://ameddregiment.amedd.army.mil/fshmuse/tour8.htmAugust 23, 2012[[Fort Sam Houston]]https://web.archive.org/web/20070717161130/http://ameddregiment.amedd.army.mil/fshmuse/tour8.htmJuly 17, 2007cite webhttp://ameddregiment.amedd.army.mil/fshmuse/eisen_football.htmLt Eisenhower and Football TeamAugust 23, 2012[[Fort Sam Houston]]https://web.archive.org/web/20070717161130/http://ameddregiment.amedd.army.mil/fshmuse/eisen_football.htmJuly 17, 2007He graduated in the middle of the class of 1915,cite webMay 23, 2008http://www.ipl.org/div/potus/ddeisenhower.htmlDwight David Eisenhower[[Internet Public Library]]which became known as "the class the stars fell on", because 59 members eventually becamegeneral officers.
article.heading: Personal life
article.paragraph: File:Mamie eisenhower.gifthumb200pxMamie EisenhowerEisenhower met and fell in love withMamie EisenhowerMamie Geneva DoudofBoone, Iowa, six years his junior, while he was stationed in Texas.rbarnett19421109He and her family were also immediately taken with one another. He proposed to her on Valentine's Day in 1916.cite webhttp://www.fhwa.dot.gov/publications/publicroads/03mar/05.cfmThe Man Who Changed America, Part IRichard F. Weingrofffhwa.dot.govMarch–April 2003A November wedding date in Denver was moved up to July 1 due to the pending U.S. entry into World War I. In their first 35 years of marriage, they moved many times.Ambrose (1983), pp. 5960.

The Eisenhowers had two sons. Doud Dwight "Icky" Eisenhower was born September 24, 1917, and died ofscarlet feveron January 2, 1921, at the age of three;Cite bookBerger-Knorr, LawrenceThe Pennsylvania Relations of Dwight D. Eisenhower8Eisenhower was mostly reticent to discuss his death.rbeckettTheir second son,John EisenhowerJohn Sheldon Doud Eisenhower, was born on August 3, 1922, while they were in Panama. John served in theUnited States Army, retired as a brigadier general, became an author and served asDiplomatic missions of BelgiumU.S. Ambassador to Belgiumfrom 1969 to 1971. John, coincidentally, graduated fromWest Pointon D-Day, June 6, 1944. He married Barbara Jean Thompson on June 10, 1947. John and Barbara had four children:David EisenhowerDwight David II, Barbara Ann,Susan EisenhowerSusan ElaineandMary Jean EisenhowerMary Jean. David, after whomCamp Davidis named,"Camp David" at the Dwight D. Eisenhower Presidential Library, Museum, and Boyhood Home site. Says "Ike re-named it 'Camp David' in honor of his grandson David Eisenhower." Retrieved August 2, 2012marriedRichard Nixon's daughterJulie Nixon EisenhowerJuliein 1968. John died on December 21, 2013.

Eisenhower was a golf enthusiast later in life, and joined theAugusta National Golf Clubin 1948.David Owen (author)Owen, David(1999).The Making of the Masters: Clifford Roberts, Augusta National, and Golf's Most Prestigious Tournament, Simon and Schuster, ISBN 0-684-85729-4.He played golf frequently during and after his presidency and was unreserved in expressing his passion for the game, to the point of golfing during winter, and ordered his golf balls painted black so he could see them better against snow on the ground. He had a small, basic golf facility installed atCamp David, and became close friends with the Augusta National ChairmanClifford Roberts, inviting Roberts to stay at theWhite Houseon several occasions; Roberts, an investment broker, also handled the Eisenhower family's investments. Roberts also advised Eisenhower on tax aspects of publishing his memoirs, which proved financially lucrative.

After golf,oil paintingwas Eisenhower's second hobby.rbeckettWhile at Columbia University, Eisenhower began the art after watchingThomas E. Stephenspaint Mamie's portrait. Eisenhower painted about 260 oils during the last 20 years of his life to relax, mostly landscapes but also portraits of subjects such as Mamie, their grandchildren, General Montgomery,George Washington, andAbraham Lincoln.cite newshttp://articles.latimes.com/1990-11-17/local/me-4317_1_nixon-libraryNew Exhibit Offers a Look at Eisenhower the ArtistLos Angeles TimesNovember 17, 1990January 13, 2012Dodson, MarcidaWendy Beckettstated that Eisenhower's work, "simple and earnest, rather cause us to wonder at the hidden depths of this reticent president". A conservative in both art and politics, he in a 1962 speech denounced modern art as "a piece of canvas that looks like a broken-downTin Lizzie, loaded with paint, has been driven over it."cite journalhttp://www.whha.org/whha_publications/publications_documents/whitehousehistory_21.pdf.President Eisenhower: PainterBeckett, WendyWhite House History2130–40harv

Angels in the Outfield (1951 film)Angels in the Outfieldwas Eisenhower's favorite movie.cite webEricksonHalAngels in the Outfield (1951): Review Summaryhttp://movies.nytimes.com/movie/83734/Angels-in-the-Outfield/overviewNew York TimesSeptember 25, 2013His favorite reading material for relaxation were the Western novels ofZane Grey.cite bookSchaeperThomas J.Rhodes Scholars, Oxford, and the Creation of an American Elite2010Berghahn BooksOxford, NY978-1845457211210With his excellent memory and ability to focus, Eisenhower was skilled at card games. He learned poker, which he called his "favorite indoor sport," in Abilene. Eisenhower recorded West Point classmates' poker losses for payment after graduation, and later stopped playing because his opponents resented having to pay him. A classmate reported that after learning to playcontract bridgeat West Point, Eisenhower played the game six nights a week for five months.cite bookEisenhower in War and PeaceRandom HouseSmith, Jean Edward201231–32, 38978-0-679-64429-3
